Planning and Land Use Management Second Amendment

longTitle.p: To provide for the Municipal Spatial Development Framework and the land use scheme of the Municipality; to provide for the development of the package of plans; to regulate and manage spatial and land use planning and development; to provide for the categorisation of land development applications; to provide for processes and procedures for land development applications; to provide for compliance with the land use scheme; to provide for an Appeal Authority; to provide for offences and penalties and to provide for matters incidental thereto.

preamble.p: WHEREAS the Municipality has competence in terms of Part B of Schedule 4 of the Constitution to administer matters pertaining to municipal planning;
WHEREAS the Municipality must contribute to the progressive realisation of fundamental rights contained in the Constitution;
WHEREAS the Municipality is committed to sustainable, developmentally orientated and integrated developmental municipal planning;
WHEREAS the Municipality must promote the development principles of spatial justice; spatial sustainability; spatial resilience; efficiency and good administration in municipal planning;
WHEREAS the Municipality must observe and enforce compliance of its land use scheme;
WHEREAS the Municipality must maintain open, transparent and sound accountable practices in its planning administration;
WHEREAS the Municipality recognises the principles of co-operative government in planning matters in order to provide for open, transparent and accountable government;
AND WHEREAS the Municipality recognises the need to facilitate the involvement of the community and public participation in planning processes and developments;

NOW THEREFORE The Municipal Council of the eThekwini Metropolitan Municipality, acting in terms of section 156 read with Part B of Schedule 4 of the Constitution of the Republic of South Africa, and read with section 11 of the Local Government: Municipal Systems Act, 2000 (Act No. 32 of 2000), hereby makes the following By-law:

intro.p: The objects of this By-law are to—

content.p: provide for a package of plans which shall inform the social, economic, environmental and infrastructural development in the Municipality;
provide a uniform, effective, comprehensive, and interrelated framework for spatial planning and land use management;
provide for the inclusive, developmental, equitable and efficient planning in the spirit of co-operative governance;
provide a framework for co-operative and cross-border relationships with all spheres of Government and to ensure the integration of planning between the Municipality and neighbouring Municipalities;
provide a framework for policies, principles, norms and standards for spatial development planning and land use management;
provide a framework for the monitoring, coordination and review of the spatial planning and land use management system;
regulate land development application and decision-making procedures;
provide for the establishment, functions and operations of the Tribunal;
provide for facilitation and enforcement of land use and development measures;
provide for an appeal authority; and
provide penalties for breach of its provisions.
This By-law applies to all land which falls within the municipal area under eThekwini Municipality and is binding on all persons to the extent applicable.

chapter.heading: Planning functions of the three spheres of government

intro.p: Municipal planning, as provided for in SPLUMA, consists of the following elements:

content.p: the compilation, approval and review of IDPs;

the compilation, approval and review of the components of an IDP prescribed by legislation and falling within the competence of a municipality, including a spatial development framework and a land use scheme; and

the control and regulation of the use of land within the municipal area where the nature, scale and intensity of the land use do not affect the provincial planning mandate of provincial government or the national interest.

intro.p: Provincial planning, as provided for in SPLUMA, consists of the following elements:

content.p: the compilation, approval and review of a provincial spatial development framework, approval, review and implementation of land use management systems;
the planning by a province for the efficient and sustainable execution of its legislative and executive powers insofar as they relate to the development of land and the change of land use; and
the making and review of policies and laws necessary to implement provincial planning.

intro.p: National planning, as provided for in SPLUMA, consists of the following elements:

content.p: the compilation, approval and review of spatial development plans and policies or similar instruments, including a national spatial development framework;

the planning by the national sphere for the efficient and sustainable execution of its legislative and executive powers insofar as they relate to the development of land and the change of land use; and

the making and review of policies and laws necessary to implement national planning, including the measures designed to monitor and support other spheres in the performance of their spatial planning, land use management and land development functions.

section.heading: Status of Municipal Spatial Development Framework

content.p: A decision maker required or mandated to make a land development decision in terms of this By-law or any other law relating to land development, may not make a decision which is inconsistent with the Municipal Spatial Development Framework: Provided that the Tribunal may depart from the provisions of the Municipal Spatial Development Framework where site specific circumstances justify such a deviation.

intro.p: The site specific circumstances contemplated in subsection (1) include but are not limited to where—

content.p: the Municipal Council has adopted a local area plan and such plan has yet to be translated into the land use scheme; or
there is an existing pre-scheme or non-conforming use right on the land: Provided that the use right has not ceased to operate for a period of 18 months or more.
The Tribunal must take into consideration the impact, amenity and land use applicability when making a decision to deviate based on site specific circumstances.

The Municipality must keep a register containing information regarding the type of deviation and reason for the deviation, in respect of any decisions taken to deviate from the provisions of the Municipal Spatial Development Framework.

section.heading: Preparation and application of Municipal Spatial Development Framework

intro.p: The Municipality must prepare a Municipal Spatial Development Framework that—

content.p: interprets and represents the spatial development vision of the Municipality;
is informed by a long-term spatial development vision statement and plan;
represents the integration of all relevant sector policies and plans;
guides planning and development decisions across all sectors of government;
guides the Municipality in taking any decision or exercising any discretion in terms of SPLUMA or any other law relating to spatial planning and land use management systems;
contributes to a coherent, planned approach to spatial development;
provides clear and accessible information to the public and private sector and provides direction for investment purposes;

includes previously disadvantaged areas, areas governed by a Traditional Authority, informal settlements, slums and land holdings of state-owned enterprises and government agencies and addresses their inclusion and integration into the spatial, economic, social and environmental objectives of the relevant sphere;
addresses historical spatial imbalances in development;
identifies the long-term risks of particular spatial patterns of growth and development and the policies and strategies necessary to mitigate those risks;

provides direction for strategic developments, infrastructure investment, promotes efficient, sustainable and planned investments by all sectors and indicates priority areas for investment in land development;
promotes a rational and predictable land development environment to create trust and stimulate investment;
takes cognisance of any environmental management instrument adopted by the relevant environmental management authority;
gives effect to national legislation and policies on sustainable utilisation and protection of agricultural resources; and

considers and where necessary incorporates the outcomes of substantial public engagement including direct participation in the process through public meetings, public exhibitions, public debates and discourses in the media and any other forms or mechanisms that promote such direct involvement.
The Municipal Spatial Development Framework prepared by the Municipality must be co-ordinated, aligned and in harmony with national and provincial spatial development frameworks.

Once the Municipal Spatial Development Framework is adopted as provided for in SPLUMA, it must guide and inform the exercise of any discretion or of any decision taken in respect of a land development application.

The national spatial development framework must contribute to and give spatial expression to national development policy and plans as well as integrate and give spatial expression to policies and plans emanating from the various sectors of national government and may include any regional spatial development framework.

The provincial spatial development frameworks must contribute to and express provincial development policy as well as integrate and spatially express policies and plans emanating from the various sectors of the provincial and national spheres of government as they apply at the geographic scale of the province.

intro.p: The Municipal Spatial Development Framework must—

content.p: be prepared as part of the Municipality’s IDP in accordance with the provisions of the Systems Act; and
assist in integrating, co-ordinating, aligning and expressing development policies and plans emanating from the various sectors of the spheres of government as they apply within the municipal area.

Any spatial development framework must outline specific arrangements for prioritising, mobilising, sequencing and implementing public and private infrastructural and land development investment in the priority spatial structuring areas identified in spatial development frameworks.

section.heading: Content of Municipal Spatial Development Framework

intro.p: A Municipal Spatial Development Framework must—

content.p: give effect to the development principles and norms and standards set out in Chapter 2 of SPLUMA;
include a written and spatial representation of a five year spatial development plan for the spatial form for the Municipality;
include a long term spatial development vision statement for the municipal area which indicates a desired spatial growth and development pattern for between 10 and 20 years into the future;

identify current and future significant structuring and restructuring elements of the spatial form of the Municipality, including development corridors, activity spines and economic nodes where public and private investment will be prioritised and facilitated;
include population growth estimates for the following five years;
include estimates of the demand for housing units across different socio-economic categories and the planned location and densities of future housing developments;
include estimates of economic activity and employment trends and locations in the municipal area over a five year period;
identify, quantify and provide location requirements of engineering infrastructure and services provision for existing and future development needs over a five year period;
identify the designated areas where national or provincial inclusionary housing policy maybe applicable;

include a strategic assessment of the environmental pressures and opportunities within the municipal area, including the spatial location of environmental sensitivities, high potential agricultural and coastal access strips where applicable;
identify the designation of areas in the Municipality where incremental upgrading approaches to development and regulation will be applicable;

intro.p: identify the designation of areas in which—

content.p: more detailed local plans must be developed; and
where shortened land use development procedures may be applicable and land use schemes may be so amended;
provide the spatial expression of the co-ordination, alignment and integration of sectoral policies of all municipal departments;
determine a capital expenditure and capital investment framework for the Municipality’s development programmes depicted spatially;
determine the purpose, desired impact and structure of the land use management scheme to apply in that municipal area; and

intro.p: include an implementation plan comprising of—

content.p: sectoral requirements including budgets and resources for implementation;
necessary amendments to a land use scheme;
specification of institutional arrangements necessary for implementation;
specification of implementation targets, including dates and monitoring indicators;
specification, where necessary, of any arrangements for partnerships in the implementation process; and
take cognisance of any norms and standards issued by the Minister.

intro.p: The Development Planning Department of the Municipality—

content.p: must prepare a Municipal Spatial Development Framework (MSDF) and Wall to Wall Land Use Scheme; and
may prepare policies, strategies and special projects and one or more local evel spatial plans all of which comprises the Package of Plans and should be read in conjunction with the MSDF.

wrapUp.p: the preparation of the package of plans is to assist with translating the strategic intent of the Integrated Development Plan (IDP) and MSDF into land use guidelines and a land use scheme.

content.p: The package of plans of the Municipality as set out in the diagram below comprises a series of policies, strategies, special projects and spatial plans prepared through an integrated and iterative process and show the move from policies, strategies and strategic level plans to detailed local and site specific plans.

The Long-Term Development Framework provides a long term vision for the Municipality to achieve strategic, economic, social and environmental objectives and informs its strategic development direction, strategies and associated action in the long term (between 20-50 years).
The Integrated Development Plan (IDP) is the principal strategic planning instrument which guides and informs all planning, budgeting, management and decision-making processes in a municipality.

intro.p: The Municipal Spatial Development Framework (MSDF) is a framework that—
seeks to guide the overall spatial distribution of current and desirable land uses within a municipality in order to give effect to the vision, goals and objectives of the municipal IDP; and

content.p: provides for the strategic spatial development objectives of the Municipality in the short (0-5), medium (5-10) and long term (10-20+yr), reviewed annually, based on the Long Term Development Framework and IDP.

intro.p: The Spatial Development Plan (SDP)—

content.p: is used to consolidate, review and update information [related to Sector Plans or specific spatial planning regions; and
translates the Spatial Development intentions of the MSDF into Land Use, Transport, Environmental and Infrastructure implications.

intro.p: The local area plan (LAP) is a detailed physical plan—

content.p: informed by the recommendations of both the Municipal IDP and SDF [by extension, any relevant SDP] by translating the intentions of these broader plans into a greater level of detail; and
informing the preparation of a future Land Use Management Scheme for the Municipality.
The primary mandate and focus of precinct plans is to ensure the implementation of broader strategic spatial objectives (as reflected in the MSDFs) at the local level.

Special Projects provides for the preparation of spatial policy, strategies, plans and guidelines relating to a specific geographic area or theme and may include the City Densification Strategy, Rural Development Strategy, Transit Oriented Development Strategies or Climate Resilience Strategies for Spatial and Land Use Plans Planning etc.

Rural Settlement Plans, whilst not compulsory, assist with the testing and revision of a Wall-to-Wall Scheme. A Rural Settlement Plan is not cadastrally based but gives guidance to current and proposed land uses, access and the provision of bulk services. It acts to guide and facilitate orderly development.

The Wall to Wall Land Use Scheme provides for zoning and development control regulations and is the detailed land use management tool and provides for the allocation of potential development rights to public and privately-owned land based on the IDP, MSDF and Package of Plans.

section.heading: Adoption of a Municipal Spatial Development Framework

content.p: The Municipal Council must prepare and adopt a Municipal Spatial Development Framework which gives effect to the principles of SPLUMA and this By-law.
The Municipal Spatial Development Framework must be prepared as part of the Municipality’s IDP in accordance with the provisions of the Systems Act.

The Municipality, in the preparation and adoption of its Municipal Spatial Development Framework must ensure that its Municipal Spatial Development Framework is aligned with the provincial and national spatial development frameworks.

intro.p: Prior to the adoption of the Municipal Spatial Development Framework contemplated in subsection (1) and any proposed amendments to the Municipal Spatial Development Framework, the Municipality must—

content.p: give notice of the proposed Municipal Spatial Development Framework in two newspapers;

invite the public to submit written representations in respect of the proposed Municipal Spatial Development Framework to the Municipality within 60 days after the publication of the notice referred to in paragraph (a); and
consider all representations received in respect of the proposed Municipal Spatial Development Framework.
The Municipality must give notice in the Provincial Government Gazette and two newspapers of its adoption of a Municipal Spatial Development Framework.
The Municipal Spatial Development Framework must give effect to the intention of the IDP and provide a framework for the future spatial development of the Municipality.
The Municipal Council may on its own initiative give effect to the development principles through an amendment to the Municipal Spatial Development Framework.
The Municipality must review its land use scheme in order to achieve consistency with the Municipal Spatial Development Framework, and must do so at least every five years.

section.heading: Resolution to prepare a land use scheme

content.p: The Municipal Council must adopt a resolution to commence the preparation of a land use scheme where no land use scheme exists.

section.heading: Preparation of a land use scheme

content.p: The Municipal Council must, after public consultation, adopt a land use scheme for its entire area within five years from the commencement of SPLUMA.

intro.p: Prior to the adoption of the land use scheme contemplated in subsection (1) and before any proposed amendments to the land use scheme, the Municipality must—

content.p: give notice of the proposed land use scheme in two newspapers;
invite the public to submit written representations in respect of the proposed Land Use Scheme to the Municipality within 30 days after the publication of the notice referred to in paragraph (a); and

p.remark: [paragraph (b) substituted by section 3(a) of the Amendment By-law, 2021]

content.p: consider all representations received in respect of the proposed land use scheme.
The Municipality must advise the public by notification in two newspapers of the adoption of or amendment to the land use scheme.

The Municipality must, in the performance of its duties in terms of this By-law, allow the participation of a Traditional Authority in the manner agreed upon between the Municipality and the Traditional Authority.
The land use scheme must include suitable categories of land use zoning and regulations for the entire municipal area including areas not previously subject to a land use scheme.

intro.p: In addition to the provisions of subsection (5), the following factors shall serve as guiding principles in the adoption of a land use scheme—

content.p: any environmental management instrument adopted by the relevant environmental management authority;
the inclusion of provisions to promote the inclusion of affordable housing in residential land development;
the inclusion of land use and development incentives to promote the effective implementation of the Municipal Spatial Development Framework and other development policies;
the inclusion of land use and development provisions specifically to promote the effective implementation of national and provincial policies;
the provisions of the Municipal Spatial Development Framework and IDP;

p.remark: [paragraph (e) substituted by section 3(b) of the Amendment By-law, 2021]

content.p: any land allocation rules set by a Traditional Authority in the area concerned; and

p.remark: [paragraph (f) substituted by section 3(c) of the Amendment By-law, 2021]

content.p: engineering services to support the land Use Scheme.

p.remark: [paragraph (g) inserted by section 3(d) of the Amendment By-law, 2021]

intro.p: A land use scheme may include provisions relating to—

content.p: specific requirements relating to any special zones identified to address the development priorities of the Municipality;

p.remark: [paragraph (a) substituted by section 3(e) of the Amendment By-law, 2021]

content.p: the variation of conditions of a land use scheme other than a variation which may materially alter or affect conditions relating to the use, size and scale of buildings and the intensity or density of land use; and

p.remark: [paragraph (b) substituted by section 3(f) of the Amendment By-law, 2021]

content.p: any restrictions to development rights.

section.heading: Purpose and content of land use scheme

intro.p: A land use scheme must give effect to and be consistent with the Municipal Spatial Development Framework and determine the use and development of land within the municipal area to which it relates in order to promote—

content.p: economic growth;
social inclusion;
efficient land development;
minimal impact on public health, the environment and natural resources; and
the development principles.

intro.p: A land use scheme must include—

content.p: scheme regulations setting out the procedures and conditions relating to the use and development of land in any zone;
a map indicating the zoning of the municipal area into land use zones; and
a land use scheme register of all amendments to such land use scheme.
The land use scheme must reflect and give effect to the development principles.

section.heading: Legal effect of a land use scheme

intro.p: An adopted land use scheme—

content.p: has the force of law and all land owners and users of land, including a Municipality and an organ of state, within the municipal area are bound by the provisions of such a land use scheme;
replaces all existing schemes within the municipal area to which the land use scheme applies; and
provides for land use and development rights.

intro.p: Land may be used only for the purposes permitted—

content.p: by the land use scheme;
by a town planning scheme, until such scheme is replaced by a land use scheme; or
in terms of subsection (3).

intro.p: Where no town planning scheme or land use scheme applies to a piece of land, before a land use scheme is approved and adopted, such land may only be used in—

content.p: in accordance with an approval which was granted in terms of section 11(2) of the Town Planning Ordinance, 1949 (Act No. 27 of 1949);
in terms of an approval granted in terms of any other applicable legislation;
in terms of pre-scheme uses; or
in terms of existing non-conforming land uses.

Notwithstanding the provisions of subsection (1)(b), any land which was being lawfully used before the adoption of a land use scheme for a purpose which does not conform to the land use scheme may continue to be used for that purpose.
If the use of the land contemplated in subsection (4) is discontinued for an uninterrupted period of more than 18 months, the land may no longer be used for that purpose.
A land use scheme which is adopted must address and resolve any conflict with an existing scheme not repealed or replaced by the new land use scheme.

Where the boundaries of a municipal area are changed or altered, the affected municipalities must in consultation with each other, amend their respective land use schemes accordingly and, until the necessary amendments are effected, the provisions of the land use schemes remain in force in the areas in which they applied before the boundary changed, and the Municipalities may agree as to whom must assume responsibility for their enforcement.

section.heading: Amendment of land use scheme and rezoning

intro.p: The Municipality may, after public consultation contemplated in section 14(2), amend its land use scheme if the amendment is—

content.p: in the public interest;
to advance the interest of or in the interest of a disadvantaged community;

p.remark: [paragraph (b) substituted by section 4(a) of the Amendment By-law, 2021]

content.p: in order to further the vision and development goals of the Municipality; or

p.remark: [paragraph (c) substituted by section 4(b) of the Amendment By-law, 2021]

content.p: non material amendment.

p.remark: [paragraph (d) added by section 4(c) of the Amendment By-law, 2021]

content.p: Notwithstanding the provisions of subsection (1), the Municipality may, after public consultation contemplated in section 14(2), amend its land use scheme by zoning or rezoning any land considered necessary by the Municipality to achieve the development goals and objectives of the Municipal Spatial Development Framework.
Any amendment to the land use scheme of the Municipality affecting the scheme regulations may only be authorised by Council.

p.remark: [subsection (4) deleted by section 1 of the Amendment By-law, 2019]

section.heading: Review and monitoring of land use scheme

content.p: The Municipality may undertake a review and monitoring of its land use scheme on an annual basis and, in accordance with section 14(2), amend its land use scheme.

The Municipality must as contemplated in SPLUMA or in terms of any other applicable Planning Legislation, submit its approved land use scheme to the Premier of the KwazuluNatal province for purposes of monitoring the performance of the Municipality.

section.heading: Record of amendments for land use scheme

content.p: The Municipality must keep and maintain, in both hard and soft copies, a written record of all applications submitted together with reasons for the decision, in respect of applications for the amendment of the land use scheme.
The written record referred to in subsection (1) must be accessible to members of the public during normal office hours at the Municipality’s Regional offices.
No person may commence, carry on or continue with any land development without the prior written approval having been granted in terms of this By-law.
All land development applications must be submitted to the Municipality, as the authority of first instance.

Notwithstanding the provisions of subsection (2) above, where any authorisation is required from an organ of state, such authorisation must accompany the submission of the land development application to the Municipality.

intro.p: A land development application may be submitted by—

content.p: an owner;
a person acting on behalf of the owner in terms of a written consent to that effect or in any other capacity;
a person to whom land has been made available for development in writing by an organ of state or such person’s authorised agent; or
a service provider responsible for the provision of infrastructure, utilities or other related services.

Notwithstanding the provisions of subsection (4), all Category 1, Category 2, Category 3 and special consent applications may only be prepared and compiled by a professional, being a Registered Planner, a person registered in terms of section 18(1)(a) of the Architectural Profession Act, or a person registered in terms of section 13(1)(d) of the Geomatics Professions Act as a Land Surveyor, or a person admitted to practice as an attorney or advocate in terms of the Legal Practice Act 28 of 2014 as amended, or under the direction or in association with such a person who is registered with his or her appropriate governing body.

p.remark: [subsection (5) substituted by section 5(a) of the Amendment By-law, 2021]
[subsection (6) deleted by section 5(b) of the Amendment By-law, 2021]
[subsection (7) deleted by section 5(c) of the Amendment By-law, 2021]

content.p: Prior to the submission of any land development application contemplated in subsection (7), authorisation in terms of the Subdivision of Agricultural Land Act, 1970 (Act No. 70 of 1970) must be obtained if required.

p.remark: [subsection (8) amended by section 5(d) of the Amendment By-law, 2021]

content.p: The Municipality may conduct an initial consultation with an applicant to advise or give direction on any requirements, procedures or any other issue relating to the submission of a land development application, including whether an application may be of National or Provincial interest.

An applicant is required to obtain all such authorisations from any organ of state and comments from internal departments for submission with the land development application as the Municipality might in its discretion require.
The outcome of the consultation contemplated in subsection (1) does not confer or constitute an approval of a land development application.

If the comments or authorisations contemplated in subsection (3) result in material changes in the application, the applicant is required to recirculate the amended application to all internal departments so as to consider the impact of the amendment on their prior approval.

p.remark: [subsection (4) added by section 6 of the Amendment By-law, 2021]

section.heading: Submission of a land development application

content.p: An application for land development must be made to the Municipality on the prescribed form and signed and dated by the applicant.

intro.p: In all instances the land development application must be accompanied by—

content.p: proof of ownership of the land;
consent of the bondholder or bondholders or proof that there is no bond registered over the land;
a comprehensive motivation as outlined in schedule 1 of this Bylaw;

p.remark: [paragraph (c) substituted by section 7(a) of the Amendment By-law, 2021]

content.p: an address at which notification or service of a document may be delivered, including a physical address, facsimile or e-mail address; and
written confirmation from an applicant that there is no appeal or pending appeal in respect of an authorisation submitted with the application.

intro.p: A land development application must, where applicable, be accompanied by the documents specified hereunder to the extent that such documents are applicable to the application:

content.p: an original or certified copy of a power of attorney;

p.remark: [paragraph (a) substituted by section 7(b) of the Amendment By-law, 2021]

content.p: a certified copy of a resolution or authority authorising a person to act on behalf of a company, close corporation, trust, body corporate or home owners’ association;
a certified copy of company registration documents and proof that the company or close corporation has not been deregistered;
a certified copy of a trust deed and letters of authority;
a copy of the Surveyor General’s diagram or general plan;
any written comments by the applicant in response to written comments made on an application by an internal department;
any required consents;
a consent to the giving of public notice where required;
subject to sections 21 (3) and 22 (2) above, any required authorisations from organs of state or comments from internal departments;
any other necessary plans or diagrams;
specialist studies or reports; and
proof of planning enquiry, where applicable.
In addition to subsection (3), the applicant is required to submit any other information or documents which may be required by the Municipality.
The Municipality may adopt a policy that provides for guidelines for the submission and processing of land development applications.
The Municipality must advise the applicant in writing that an application is complete.

p.remark: [subsection (1) substituted by section 8 of the Amendment By-law, 2021]

content.p: An applicant may in writing at any time prior to a decision being made, withdraw an application.
An applicant must submit a new application where an application has been withdrawn as contemplated in subsection (2).

intro.p: the municipality must refuse to accept an application if—

content.p: a planning enquiry is required but has not taken place;
the municipality has not received the application fee;
the application does not comply with an information specification, lacks necessary information required in terms of Section 23 or contains manifestly incorrect information; or

in the municipality’s opinion, a materially similar application was refused within the previous six months and there has been no relevant change in law or policy or the factual considerations upon which the decision to refuse was based have not changed.

p.remark: [section 24A inserted by section 9 of the Amendment By-law, 2021]

content.p: An Applicant who requires a town planning approval in respect of a heritage site must ensure that all the required authorisation and or clearance/s by the relevant authorities are in place prior to the submission of an application to the municipality.
The Municipality will not accept any application that is within the boundaries of a heritage site if the provisions of subsection (1) are not adhered to.

p.remark: [section 24B inserted by section 9 of the Amendment By-law, 2021]

content.p: The Municipality must categorise all land development applications.

intro.p: Any land development application which constitutes a combined application shall be

content.p: processed by the Regional offices; and
sent to the SPLUMA office, where it will be directed to and decided upon in accordance with section 27 and 28 below.

intro.p: A Category 1 determination must be considered, approved and adopted by the Municipal Council and includes the following:

content.p: the adoption of the land use scheme; and
the amendment or review of the land use scheme.

intro.p: A Category 2 application must be considered and decided by the Tribunal and includes—

content.p: land development applications where there is a departure from the provisions of the Municipal Spatial Development Framework;
an application for rezoning of land where objections to the application have been lodged;
an introduction of a new area and an existing zone into the land use schemes;
zoning of land; and
a combined application, which includes one or more of the land development uses set out in (a) to (d) as well as any land uses falling within category 3 and 4.

A Category 3 application must be considered and decided upon by the Head: Provided that where an objection has been lodged during the public participation process in respect of an application for the rezoning of land contemplated in subsection 2(f), the Tribunal must consider and decide upon such application.

intro.p: A category 3 application includes—

content.p: a special consent application;
an application for subdivision;
an application for consolidation;

p.remark: [paragraph (c) substituted by section 10(a) of the Amendment By-law, 2021]

content.p: an application for a township establishment;
an application for the closure of roads and public open spaces;
an application for the rezoning of land which is in line with the Municipal Spatial Development Framework;
an application for the removal, amendment or suspension of a restrictive condition;
an application for the development of land outside of a land use scheme; and
a combined application, which includes one or more of the land development uses set out in (a) to (h) above as well as any land uses falling within category 4 land development applications.
a non material amendment.

p.remark: [paragraph (j) added by section 10(b) of the Amendment By-law, 2021]

content.p: A Category 4 application must be considered and decided upon by the Deputy Head.

intro.p: A Category 4 application includes—

content.p: an application for a relaxation where the necessary notification has been issued;

p.remark: [paragraph (a) substituted by section 11(a) of the Amendment By-law, 2021]

content.p: an application for written consent from the provisions of the land use scheme where the necessary notification or notifications have been issued;

p.remark: [paragraph (b) substituted by section 11(b) of the Amendment By-law, 2021]

content.p: [paragraph (c) deleted by section 11(c) of the Amendment By-law, 2021]; and
an application for the development of land outside of a scheme in respect of an application for a relaxation or exemption where the necessary consent or consents have been obtained.
The Joint Advisory Committee is hereby established.
The function of the Joint Advisory Committee is to make recommendations to the decision maker on land development applications.
The Head shall appoint a minimum of four municipal officials who are Registered Planners to serve as members on the Joint Advisory Committee.
The Head shall appoint a Chairperson from the members.
In the event that the Chairperson is unavailable, one of the Regional Co-ordinators shall be nominated to chair the meeting.
Three members of the Joint Advisory Committee must be present in order for a meeting to proceed.
The Joint Advisory Committee must meet as often as is required in order to perform its functions.
The Head shall determine the internal procedures and processes of the Joint Advisory Committee.

p.remark: [subsection (9) deleted by section 12 of the Amendment By-law, 2021]
[subsection (10) deleted by section 12 of the Amendment By-law, 2021]

content.p: The Joint Advisory Committee must submit its recommendations to the decision maker within 14 days of having made such recommendation.
The Head may make a recommendation for approval or refusal of any circulated application received by an internal line department for comment.

section.heading: Types of land development applications which require public participation

intro.p: An applicant must give public notice of a land development application in the manner stipulated in this chapter for the following types of applications:

content.p: special consent applications;
zoning and re-zoning applications;
removal, amendment or suspension of restrictive conditions applications;
closure of roads and public open spaces; and
any Category 2 application.

intro.p: An applicant shall only be required to serve written notice of a land development application on adjoining owners, and where applicable, affected owners for issuing notification for the following types of applications—

content.p: an application for written consent; and

p.remark: [paragraph (a) substituted by section 13(b) of the Amendment By-law, 2021]

content.p: an application for relaxation.

p.remark: [subsection (2) amended by section 13(a) of the Amendment By-law, 2021]

content.p: Where an adjoining owner or affected owner has been notified as contemplated in subsection (2) above, and wish to object to the consent, they should furnish the Municipality with valid reasons for objecting to such consent.

p.remark: [subsection (3) substituted by section 13(c) of the Amendment By-law, 2021]

content.p: Failure to submit any comments or valid reasons to the notification within the stipulated period will be deemed as consent.

p.remark: [subsection (4) added by section 13(d) of the Amendment By-law, 2021]

content.p: An applicant may proceed to give public notice in respect of a land development application once the municipality has confirmed in writing that the application is complete.

p.remark: [subsection (1) substituted by section 14 of the Amendment By-law, 2021]

content.p: The applicant must commence with public notice in the manner and form provided for in section 34 within 14 days of receipt of the notification contemplated in subsection (1).

intro.p: The Municipality may, where it deems it impractical to serve notices on all affected and adjoining owners, for the purposes of public participation call for a public meeting and publish a notice in a newspaper inviting–

content.p: interested and affected persons to attend a public meeting; and
objections from the public, to be received by the Municipality by a specified date not less than 30 days after the publication of the notice.
The public meeting contemplated in subsection (3) must be held not less than seven days and not more than 60 days after the date of the publication of the notice referred to in subsection (3).

intro.p: A notice appearing in the newspapers, a site notice and the notice served on adjoining owners, affected owners, organs of state and the ward councillor must contain the following information:

content.p: full names of the applicant;
capacity in which the applicant is acting if he or she is not the owner of the land concerned;
full property description, location or other means of identifying the property;
brief summary of the application;
name of person and address where written objections may be lodged;

intro.p: that written objections must be lodged with the Municipality within 30 days of–

content.p: publication of the notice in the newspaper;
delivery of the notice; or
display of the site notice;

p.remark: [paragraph (f) substituted by section 15(a) of the Amendment By-law, 2021]

content.p: place and time where particulars of the application may be inspected; and
any other additional information which the Municipality may require to be included in the notice.

intro.p: An applicant must give notice of a land development application by:

content.p: publication thereof once in two local newspapers that circulate in the area: Provided that where the dates of publication differ, the date of the last publication is deemed to be the date of publication; and

simultaneously using other means, which may be required by the municipality which may include announcements through a loudhailer, publication on the municipal website where a copy of the application will be made available for inspection, community notice boards or communication through email or social media.

p.remark: [subsection (2) substituted by section 15(b) of the Amendment By-law, 2021]

content.p: A notice contemplated in subsection (2) must be published in the language of the newspaper.

An applicant must, on or before the date of the publication in the newspapers contemplated in subsection (2), display the site notice or notices and serve a written notice on adjoining owners, affected owners, organs of state and the ward councillor.
An applicant must display a site notice or site notices on all road frontages.

intro.p: The site notice or site notices displayed must be—

content.p: A3 in size and in accordance with the manner and form prescribed by the Municipality in respect of the content and location of the notice or notices; and
displayed in a legible condition for the duration of the period for public notice.
An applicant is liable for all costs associated with the giving of public notice.

Where an adjoining owner or affected owner is a member of a Body Corporate or Home Owners Association, service on the registered adress of Body Corporate or Home Owners Association is deemed to be service on all the owners of the Body Corporate or Home Owners Association.

p.remark: [subsection (8) substituted by section 15(c) of the Amendment By-law, 2021]

content.p: An applicant must provide proof of publication in the newspapers by lodging the full newspaper tear sheets with the Municipality within seven days of date of closing of the period allowed for the lodging of objections.

intro.p: In addition to the proof contemplated in subsection (1), the applicant must simultaneously submit to the Municipality—

content.p: proof of service of the notice on adjoining owners, affected owners, any organ of state and the ward councillor;
an affidavit confirming display of the site notice or site notices for the period concerned; and

p.remark: [paragraph (b) substituted by section 16 of the Amendment By-law, 2021]

intro.p: photographs confirming display of the site notice which must—

content.p: be legible and clear showing the position, wording and visibility of notice; and
contain the date on which the photograph was taken.
A written objection in respect of any land development application must be served on the Municipality within the 30 day period allowed for the lodging of objections.

p.remark: [subsection (1) substituted by section 17(a) of the Amendment By-law, 2021]

content.p: The Municipality must provide the applicant with the objections as soon as reasonably possible, but not more than seven days after the expiry of objection period. An applicant may submit to the Municipality a written response to any objection lodged within 21 days of receiving the objections.

p.remark: [subsection (2) substituted by section 17(b) of the Amendment By-law, 2021]

intro.p: An objection must contain the following information–

content.p: the name and physical address of the person making the objection;
the address at which the person shall receive service of any notice, which may include a facsimile or e-mail address;
the interest of the person in the application;
the reason for the objection; and
the reason for any request made for an extension of the period for the submission of objections.
An objection that fails to meet the requirements of subsection (3) will be deemed invalid.

p.remark: [subsection (4) added by section 17(c) of the Amendment By-law, 2021]

content.p: The Head may permit an applicant to amend his or her application prior to a decision being made where such proposed amendment does not change the nature of the application.

intro.p: Where the Head permits an amended application as contemplated in subsection (1), he or she may—

content.p: require the applicant to re-circulate the amended application to internal departments and organs of state for comment; and
if required, determine the manner and form of any further public participation which the applicant may be required to undertake.

Where the Head requires an applicant to undertake public participation for an amended application as contemplated in subsection (2)(b), any person who lodged objections previously to the application shall be advised that their previously submitted objections shall lapse and only objections submitted during the public participation process for the amended application shall be considered.
The Municipality must establish a Tribunal to consider and decide land development applications assigned to it in terms of this By-law.
The Tribunal must consist of officials in the full-time service of the Municipality and external persons appointed by the Municipal Council.
A Municipal Councillor may not be appointed as a member of the Tribunal.
The Tribunal must exercise its powers in an independent manner and in accordance with the principles of integrity, impartiality, objectivity and professionalism.
The Municipality, an organ of state or any other person may not interfere with the functioning of the Tribunal.
A member of the Tribunal shall serve impartially and carry out or perform his or her powers, duties and functions in good faith and without fear, favour or prejudice.

The Tribunal may issue a written directive to any official or employee within the Municipality, compelling him or her to appear before the Tribunal for the purposes of providing information relevant to the application before it.

section.heading: Procedure to appoint a member of the Tribunal

content.p: The Municipality must, by notice in two newspapers, call for nominations for the appointment of external persons to be members of the Tribunal.

intro.p: Any external person who responds to the notice must—

content.p: lodge a written application in the prescribed form together with supporting documents within the prescribed timeframes; and
comply with the requirements and criteria for appointment to the Tribunal.

The Municipality must constitute an evaluation panel comprised of municipal officials who shall make recommendations to Council in respect of the appointment of external persons to serve on the Tribunal.

Any person appointed to serve on the Tribunal must be provided with a letter of appointment containing the terms and conditions of such appointment as may be determined by the Council and in accordance with any applicable norms and standards.

A designated official is bound by his or her conditions of service and is not entitled to any additional remuneration, allowances, leave or sick leave or other employee benefits as a result of his or her membership on the Tribunal.

The Tribunal may only commence operations after the Municipal Manager has placed a notice in the Provincial Gazette confirming the constitution of the Tribunal, the names of the members of the Tribunal and its date of commencement.
The Municipality must call for further nominations in accordance with the process set out in this section where nominations received do not meet the stipulated criteria.

intro.p: The Tribunal must consist of—

content.p: designated officials in the full-time service of the Municipality; and
external persons appointed by the Municipal Council.

Any person designated or appointed as a member of the Tribunal must have the relevant qualifications, professional registrations where applicable, knowledge of and practical experience in spatial planning, land use management and land development or the law related thereto.

intro.p: The designated officials in the full-time service of the Municipality must be—

content.p: a Registered Planner;
a registered Environmental Practitioner;

p.remark: [paragraph (b) substituted by section 18(a) of the Amendment By-law, 2021]

content.p: a Senior Legal Advisor, Chief Legal Advisor, Deputy Head or Head of the Municipality’s Legal and Compliance Unit; and

p.remark: [paragraph (c) substituted by section 18(b) of the Amendment By-law, 2021]

content.p: a registered traffic engineer.

p.remark: [paragraph (d) added by section 18(c) of the Amendment By-law, 2021]

intro.p: The external persons appointed by the Municipal Council must be—

content.p: a Registered Planner who has experience in Strategic Planning; and
a Registered Planner who has experience in the submission of land use applications.

50% percent plus 1 of the number of members of the Tribunal constitute a quorum for a meeting: Provided that a Registered Planner and a legal official contemplated in section 40 (3)(c) must be present in order for a meeting to proceed.
The Tribunal may, in the performance of its duties, co-opt, appoint or employ the services of a technical adviser or a specialist in the field of concern.
A technical adviser or a specialist contemplated in subsection (6) is not a member of and has no voting rights in the proceedings of the Tribunal.
A technical adviser who is not a public service official or in the employ of the Municipality may be remunerated accordingly.

The term of office of members of the Tribunal is five years or such shorter period as the Council may determine, provided that a member may not serve as a member for a continuous period of more than ten years.

A Municipality may designate a municipal official as a temporary member of the Tribunal, in place of a member designated as such in terms of paragraph (1)(a), where such member has been indisposed due to ill health or maternity leave and has been granted a leave of absence by the Chairperson.
The member appointed on a temporary basis in terms of subsection (10) must be employed by the Municipality in the same professional capacity as the member he or she is substituting.
The Council must designate a member of the Tribunal to serve as Chairperson and such person must hold office for a term not exceeding five years.
The Council must designate a member of the Tribunal as Deputy Chairperson and such person must hold office for a term not exceeding five years.

The Deputy Chairperson must act as Chairperson of the Tribunal when the Chairperson is absent or is unable to perform his or her duties: Provided that in the event that both the Chairperson and Deputy Chairperson are absent or are unable to perform their duties, the members may elect another member to preside for the duration of the meeting.
The Chairperson, or where applicable the Deputy Chairperson, is the signatory of the Tribunal.
The Chairperson must direct the work of the Tribunal, represent the Tribunal in all administrative matters and preside at the meetings of the Tribunal.
The Chairperson shall determine the times and places for meetings of the Tribunal.
The Chairperson is assisted by the SPLUMA office in the execution of his or her management duties.
A decision of a majority of the members of the Tribunal is a final decision of the Tribunal.
If on any question there is an equality of votes, the presiding officer who has been appointed for the meeting, shall have the deciding vote in addition to that member’s vote as a member.

section.heading: Term of office of external members of Tribunal

p.remark: [heading substituted by section 19 of the Amendment By-law, 2021]

content.p: The Municipal Council may appoint an external member to serve on the Tribunal for five years or such shorter period as the Council may determine.

intro.p: A person may not be appointed or continue to serve as a member of the Tribunal, if he or she—

content.p: is not a citizen or permanent resident of the Republic of South Africa;
is a member of or has been nominated as a member of Parliament, a Provincial legislature, any municipal council or House of Traditional Leaders;
is an unrehabilitated insolvent;
has been declared by a court of law to be mentally incompetent or has been detained under the Mental Health Care Act, 2002 (Act No. 17 of 2002);
has at any time been convicted of an offence involving dishonesty;
has at any time been removed from an office of trust on account of misconduct;
has previously been removed from a Tribunal for a breach of any provision of SPLUMA, provincial legislation enacted in terms of SPLUMA or this By-law;
has been found guilty of misconduct, incapacity or incompetence;
fails to comply with the provisions of SPLUMA, any provincial legislation enacted in terms of SPLUMA or this By-law;
is declared incapable of managing his or her own affairs by a court of law or is placed under curatorship;
fails to disclose an interest and proceeds to participate in a meeting;
is absent for two consecutive meetings without a leave of absence being granted by the Chairperson; or
is a member of the Joint Advisory Committee.
A member of the Tribunal must immediately vacate office if that member becomes subject to a disqualification contemplated in subsection (1).

intro.p: A vacancy in the Tribunal occurs when—

content.p: a member resigns in writing;
the term of office of the member has expired;
a member dies; or
a member is subject to a disqualification contemplated in subsection (1).
If a vacancy exists, the Tribunal shall not be prevented from carrying out its functions and the Municipality must immediately appoint or designate a member to the Tribunal.

The Council may remove an external member of the Tribunal from office after he or she has been given an opportunity to submit representations in response to the grounds upon which his or her removal from office have been based.

A member of the Tribunal may not absent himself or herself from a meeting without the prior written approval of the Chairperson, and must make provision for the proper performance of his or her duties during any absence.
A breach by an employee must be dealt with in accordance with the disciplinary procedures of the Municipality contained in section 67(1)(h) of the Systems Act.

intro.p: A member of the Tribunal—

content.p: must make full disclosure of any conflict of interest, including any potential conflict within the prescribed period; and
may not attend, participate or vote in any proceedings of the Tribunal in relation to any matter in respect of which the member has a conflict of interest.

intro.p: A member of the Tribunal has a conflict of interest if—

content.p: the member, an immediate family member, partner or business associate of the member is the applicant or has a pecuniary or other interest in the matter before the Tribunal; or
the member has any other interest that may preclude or may reasonably be perceived as precluding the member from performing the functions of the member in a fair, unbiased and proper manner.

intro.p: If at any stage during the course of a meeting, it appears that a member has or may have a conflict of interest, the—

content.p: member must fully disclose the nature of the conflict of interest and leave the meeting; and
disclosure must be recorded in the minutes of the meeting.
The Municipal Manager must keep a register of all disclosures of conflict of interest made by members of the Tribunal.
All members of the Tribunal must adhere to the Municipality’s Code of Conduct for members of the Tribunal.

A member of the Tribunal who is in the full-time service of the Municipality must, in addition to the Code of Conduct referred to in subsection (12), adhere to the provisions of the Code of Conduct for Municipal Staff Members as provided for in Schedule 2 of the Systems Act.

The Municipality may indemnify and provide legal representation to a member of the Tribunal or Appeal Authority or a decision maker where legal proceedings have been instituted against such person arising out of any act in the performance of their duties or exercise of their powers and where they acted in good faith and without negligence in accordance with the provisions of any policy adopted by Council setting out the terms and conditions for indemnification.

intro.p: When deliberating on any application, a decision maker must, where applicable, consider the following, which includes but is not limited to—

content.p: the Constitution;
the Constitutional transformation imperatives and the related duties of organs of state;
the development principles;
the type of application and motivation submitted by the applicant;
the procedure followed in assessing the application;
the IDP and Municipal Spatial Development Framework;
the developmental goals and vision of the Municipality;
the provisions of the land use scheme;
the national and provincial Spatial Development Frameworks and, where applicable, regional Spatial Development Frameworks;
the package of plans;
any objections or comments lodged in response to the public participation process or filed by persons who have been granted intervener status;
any written response lodged by an applicant to objections or comments received or filed by persons granted intervener status;
any comments received from internal departments and organs of state;
public interest;
the state and impact of the application on engineering services, social infrastructure and open space requirements;
development charges applicable under law at the time of lodgement of the application;
the facts and circumstances relevant to the application, including the matters referred to in the Planning and Development Act as being relevant to the type of application concerned;
the respective rights and obligations of all those affected by the application;
written evaluation and recommendation of the Regional office;
compliance with environmental legislation and any other applicable legislation dealing with planning and land use management;
recommendations made by the Joint Advisory Committee;
the role and interest of a Traditional Authority in the application;
any applicable policy of the Municipality with regards to decision making, planning and land use management;
any other factor which to the mind of the decision maker is relevant, including timeframes for making decisions;
policies, principles, norms and standards or other guidelines set by National and Provincial Government; and
section 42 of SPLUMA.

intro.p: The decision notice must contain the following information:

content.p: the details of the application;
the outcome of the application;
the reasons for the decision contemplated in paragraph (b);
any conditions subject to which the application was approved;
any directives in respect of the Surveyor-General, where applicable;
the reason for any changes made to the application;
the closing date for the lodgement of an appeal; and
the effective date of the Municipality’s decision.
Any clerical mistake or error in any document recording a decision may be corrected by the presiding officer of the Tribunal, the Head or Deputy Head as the category of application requires.

section.heading: Functions and powers of the decision maker

intro.p: A decision maker must—

content.p: consider and determine all applications lawfully referred or submitted to it;
consider the recommendations submitted by the Joint Advisory Committee before making a decision on an application;
keep a record of all proceedings;
provide written reasons for any decisions taken; and
keep a register of all decision notices.

intro.p: The decision maker may—

content.p: impose any reasonable conditions including conditions related to the provision of engineering services and the payment of any development charges in terms of any applicable law at the time of lodgement of the application;

amend or waive a condition imposed by it: Provided that the Municipality must give notice to any person affected by it or in whose favour the condition was imposed, and only after considering any representation made by such persons regarding the proposed amendment or waiver;
make an appropriate determination regarding all matters necessary or incidental to the performance of its functions in terms of SPLUMA, any applicable Provincial legislation and this By-law;
conduct an investigation into any matter relevant to an application under its consideration.
request the Council to designate a municipal official or appoint any other person in terms of section 32 (3) of SPLUMA as an inspector to conduct an investigation;
request further information from the applicant;
give directions relevant to its decision making functions to any person in the service of the Municipality;
conduct a site inspection;
decide on any question concerning its own jurisdiction;
appoint a technical adviser to advise or assist in the performance of their functions in terms of SPLUMA and this By-law; and

make a determination as to whether a person qualifies as an interested person to be granted intervener status in a land development application and may limit the interested person’s participation to only those issues in respect of which their interest has been established.

intro.p: The decision maker may—

content.p: approve an application in whole or in part;
approve an application subject to conditions;
refuse an application; or

postpone its decision on an application in order for a site inspection or other investigations to be conducted, or for technical advice or further information requested form the applicant to be obtained: Provided the decision may not be postponed for a period exceeding 30 days.
The Tribunal may request a hearing and must notify the applicant, any person who lodged an objection and any person who was granted intervener status, of the date, time and place of the hearing.

intro.p: Where applicable, the notice of the hearing contemplated in subsection (2) must—

content.p: specify the place, date and time of hearing;
state the purpose of the hearing;
inform parties of their right to be present or to be represented at the hearing;
inform parties of their right to state their case or lead evidence in support of their case; and
include any other necessary information.
The applicant and any person who intends to be present at the hearing must inform the Tribunal of their intention prior to the hearing.

The persons contemplated in subsection (2) may be permitted to call one or more expert witnesses and must furnish the Tribunal and parties to the hearing with a summary of the expert witnesses’ evidence seven days prior to the hearing.

The summary of the evidence to be given by an expert witness must contain at least sufficient information to enable the other party to determine the basis for the expert’s opinion and the extent to which he or she agrees or disagrees with the evidence of such expert.
The Tribunal must where a hearing was held in respect of an application, make a decision on the application within 30 days of the last day of the hearing.

Subject to section 45(1) of this By-law, the Tribunal must where there was no hearing for an application, make a decision on an application within seven days of receiving the recommendation from the Joint Advisory Committee.
Subject to section 45(1) of this By-law, the Head or Deputy Head must make a decision on an application within seven days of receiving the recommendation from the Joint Advisory Committee.

The decision maker must forward the signed and dated decision notice to the applicant and to any person who objected, any person who was granted intervener status, the Regional Co-ordinator, service provider, organ of state and any other person or body where applicable, within seven days of making a decision.

The decision maker must, if unable to make a decision on the application within the time specified, notify the applicant in writing of any such delay and provide the reasons thereof, together with an indication as to the date when a decision on the application can be expected.
Where a decision maker has refused an application, the Municipality may permit the applicant to submit a new application only where such person can demonstrate a change in circumstances.

Where no appeal has been lodged, the decision becomes effective on the day following the expiry of the prescribed period for the lodgement of an appeal: Provided that where public participation was not required for an application and the applicant has waived their right of appeal, the decision is effective on the date of the decision.

The Municipality must advise all parties contemplated in subsection (10) in writing of the effective date of the decision within seven days of the date of expiry of the period contemplated in subsection (13).
Where an appeal has been lodged in terms of the By-law, the decision is suspended pending the outcome of the appeal.

section.heading: Effective date of Municipal Planning Approval Authority’s decision on application

intro.p: A decision on an application for municipal planning approval comes into effect upon―
the date of the Record of Decision, if―

content.p: no comments were received in response to an invitation for the public to comment on the application;
no person has applied for leave to intervene contemplated in section 86(1) before the application was decided; and
the applicant has waived the right to appeal;

intro.p: the expiry of the 21 day period contemplated in section 60(1), if―

content.p: comments were received in response to an invitation for the public to comment on the application;
a person has applied for leave to intervene contemplated in section 86(1) before the application was decided; or
the applicant has not waived the right to appeal;

the date upon which the Presiding Officer of the Municipal Planning Appeal Authority confirmed that an appeal is invalid, if an applicant or a Municipality successfully made an urgent application to declare an appeal invalid, unless the application for municipal planning approval is subject to another valid appeal;

intro.p: the date upon which the Presiding Officer of the Municipal Planning Appeal Authority has confirmed that―

content.p: a decision on an application for municipal planning approval may commence in respect of land that is not affected by the appeal; or

parts of a decision for municipal planning approval that are not affected by the appeal may commence, if an applicant or the Municipality successfully made an urgent application for the partial commencement of a decision to approve an application for municipal approval;
the date upon which an appeal is withdrawn, unless the application for municipal planning approval is subject to another appeal;

intro.p: the finalisation of an appeal, if an appeal was lodged against the decision of a Municipal Planning Authorised Official, or the Municipal Planning Tribunal and―

content.p: the Chairperson of the Municipal Planning Appeal Authority has not declared the appeal invalid; or

granted approval for the partial commencement of the decision of the Municipal Planning Approval Authority in respect of the properties or parts of the decision of the Municipal Planning Approval Authority.

p.remark: [section 46A inserted by section 20 of the Amendment By-law, 2021]

section.heading: Conditional approval of land development application

content.p: An application may be approved subject to such conditions as determined by the decision maker.

intro.p: A conditional approval of an application lapses if a condition is not complied with, within—

content.p: a period of two years from date of such approval, if no period for compliance is specified in such approval; or
the period for compliance specified in such approval, which, together with any extension which may be granted, may not exceed five years.

A decision notice must provide the period for which such approval shall be valid and the approval shall lapse if, where applicable, no building plan has been submitted to the Municipality within the specified period: Provided that the Municipality may on request and prior to the lapsing extend the validity period.

Where an activity requires a land development application approval and building plan approval, the approval of the land development application must be obtained prior to an approval for a building plan being granted: Provided that an approval granted in terms of this By-Law does not confer an approval in terms of the National Building Regulations and Building Standards Act, 1977 (Act No. 103 of 1977).
An applicant must advise the Municipality in writing when he or she is ready to commence operations on the land.

intro.p: The Municipality must certify that the conditions of approval have been complied with prior to the—

content.p: erection of a structure on the land or the use of land in accordance with the approval;
construction of a building on the land;
occupation of the land; or
registration of the land in separate ownership, as the nature of the condition may require.

The provisions of subsection (6) do not prohibit the use of the land for the purposes it was lawfully used before the approval of the application unless the decision maker has directed otherwise in the conditions of approval.

intro.p: An agreement for the alienation of a subdivision or consolidation of land that was approved by the Municipality but for which it has not issued a certificate that the applicant has complied with the conditions of approval before it may be registered in separate ownership must contain a clause disclosing that the—

content.p: applicant has not as yet complied with the conditions of approval; and
property is not registerable as contemplated in section 1 of the Alienation of Land Act, 1981 (Act No. 68 of 1981).

section.heading: Notification to Surveyor-General and Registrar of Deeds

intro.p: A decision maker must, within the prescribed period after a land use decision affecting the use of land not in accordance with a condition in a title deed, notify the—

content.p: Registrar of Deeds in whose office the deed or document is filed of such approval; and
Office of the Surveyor-General, where such approval affects a diagram or general plan filed in that office.

section.heading: Removal, amendment and suspension of restrictive conditions

intro.p: The Municipality shall not permit an application to be lodged for the removal, amendment or suspension of a restrictive condition in respect of a—

content.p: registered mining right;
condition in favour of the KwaZulu-Natal Conservation Board without the Board’s written consent to remove, amend or suspend the condition;
condition in favour of the South African Roads Board imposed in terms of the South African Road Boards Act, 1988 (Act No. 74 of 1988);
condition imposed by South African National Roads Agency Limited (SANRAL);
condition imposed by a Member of the Executive Council in terms of the KwaZuluNatal Provincial Roads Act, 2001 (Act No. 4 of 2001);
condition relating to the sale of land, including a right to purchase property and a condition that the value of a building must exceed a minimum amount; or
condition relating to the inheritance of land, including a condition that grants a person the right to use the land for the person’s lifetime.
A condition in a title deed relating to omnibus and general servitudes may only be amended with the permission of the Municipality.

In considering an application to remove, amend or suspend a restrictive condition, the decision maker is not liable to compensate any person for any loss arising from or related to a decision made in good faith.

p.remark: [subsection (4) deleted by section 21(a) of the Amendment By-law, 2021]

intro.p: A Conveyancer’s Certificate must be lodged with an application for the removal, amendment or suspension of a condition confirming that—

content.p: he or she has examined the title deed; and
no further conditions of title shall be affected by the removal, amendment or suspension of the condition.

An applicant must submit the original title deed together with the decision notice, the certificate issued by the Municipality confirming compliance with conditions of approval, to the Registrar of Deeds and Surveyor-General within the prescribed timeframes in order for the appropriate entries and endorsements on any relevant register, title deed, diagram or plan to be made in the respective offices.

p.remark: [subsection (6) substituted by section 21(b) of the Amendment By-law, 2021]

content.p: The approval of a land development application for township establishment may be subject to conditions of establishment.
The Municipality shall together with the decision notice issue a certificate containing the conditions of establishment contemplated in subsection (1).
The Municipality must notify the Registrar of Deeds and Surveyor-General of the approval of the application and conditions of establishment imposed within 30 days of the decision.

The applicant must after the approval of the application lodge with the Surveyor-General such plans and diagrams for approval that may be necessary within the prescribed timeframes and provide the Municipality with a copy of the approved general plan and diagrams by the Surveyor-General.

An applicant may only submit a building plan to the Municipality once he or she has obtained and submitted to the Municipality all the necessary certificates evidencing that the conditions of establishment have been complied with, or has obtained written approval from the Municipality to build in advance of obtaining such certificates and complying with specified conditions of establishment.
The Municipality may permit the sale of erven in the township prior to the proclamation of the township.

intro.p: The applicant must lodge with the Municipality written proof of compliance with the conditions of establishment confirming—

content.p: compliance with the imposed conditions of establishment;

p.remark: [paragraph (a) substituted by section 22(a) of the Amendment By-law, 2021]

content.p: in order to further the vision and development goals of the Municipality; and

p.remark: [paragraph (b) substituted by section 22(b) of the Amendment By-law, 2021]

content.p: necessary guarantees for services have been provided where applicable, and as per the provisions of Schedule 3.

p.remark: [paragraph (c) added by section 22(c) of the Amendment By-law, 2021]

content.p: The Municipality shall issue a certificate to the applicant confirming compliance with subsection (7).

intro.p: The Registrar of Deeds may not permit the registration of the transfer of any erf in a township—

content.p: without the certificate issued by the Municipality confirming compliance contemplated in subsection (8);
where the Municipality has advised the Registrar that conditions of establishment have not been complied with; or
where the approval has lapsed.
The Registrar of Deeds must advise the Municipality if a general plan has been registered, of the opening of the township register and of the endorsement or registration of any deeds.

The Municipality may issue a certificate of approval of the township on notification by the Registrar of Deeds contemplated in subsection (10): Provided that where there is a phasing of the township, the applicant must obtain a certificate of approval for each phase.

A public open space or public road must, prior to or simultaneously with registration of transfer of the final erf in the township and at the cost of the applicant, be transferred to the Municipality.
A social facility must, prior to or simultaneously with registration of transfer of the first erf in the township and at the cost of the applicant, be transferred to the Municipality.

section.heading: Closure of roads and public open spaces

content.p: An application for the closure of a road or public open space may require the submission of an Environmental Impact Assessment and compliance with any other applicable legislation.
The Municipality must advise the Surveyor-General of the closure of a road and make application for the amendment of the relevant general plan.
The Registrar of Deeds must, where the ownership of the closure of a road or public open space vests in the Municipality or in another organ of state, make the necessary entries.

section.heading: Land for parks, public open spaces and social facilities

content.p: An approval of a land development application which provides for the use of land for residential purposes may be subject to the provision of land for parks, public open spaces or social facilities by the applicant.

The land required for parks, public open spaces or social facilities must be provided within the land area to which the land development application relates: Provided that the Municipality may consider an alternative land area for the provision of parks, public open spaces or social facilities where it is more feasible to do so.
